thread.title: Fiction Chronicle: Under West Indian Eyes

author: Sam Sacks
title: Fiction Chronicle: Under West Indian Eyes
text: In his muckraking memoir “Difficult Women” (1983), David Plante recounts the novelist Jean Rhys’s melancholy prediction that “people will try to uncover everything about me after I die to write it all down.” She was right, of course, and tell-all biographies have accumulated since her death in 1979, none crueler than Mr. Plante’s portrait of the artist in inebriated old age. Yes, Rhys was a thrice-married former showgirl who spent the better part of her 90 years in alcoholic penury, but she was also a crucial figure in émigré Paris’s modernist movement. She is best known as the author of “Wide Sargasso Sea” (1966), a...
